p: Ensure access to your application's log files are restricted.
Logged events often contain internal application details that could enable an attacker to more effectively target your application.
If your application generates multiple log files, use your application to generate all the log files and follow these steps to ensure they are protected:
Verify location of logs is not disclosed. Scan your application's code base to verify that the location of the log files is known only to the internal logging framework.
Ensure appropriate Access Control Lists (ACL) are set. Verify that:
Ensure that proper log management is in place. Verify that your application enforces your organization's audit policy with respect to managing its logs. Check that:
Verify that ASP.NET health monitoring is secured. If your application uses ASP.NET health monitoring (a feature that is enabled by default), check if the following measures are set in place:

An e-commerce site does hundreds of transactions an hour and logs data at the web and database levels, along with a separate security log that monitors all user and security-related events. Unfortunately, the security logs are stored in a location that is hidden in the application's directory tree. An attacker finds the location of the logs and retrieves all user and security-related events.
Adapted from Microsoft patterns & practices guidance.
ol:
Verify location of logs is not disclosed. Scan your application's code base to verify that the location of the log files is known only to the internal logging framework.
      
        
          Ensure appropriate Access Control Lists (ACL) are set. Verify that:
        
          Logs are set with the appropriate file system permissions. All entities, excluding your application and its administrators/developers, are prohibited access to the logs. If your application logs are backed up, verify that the backups are stored in an environment that is secure. Log files are located on a non-system NTFS volume and not on the same volume where the Web site content resides.
        
        
          
            Ensure that proper log management is in place. Verify that your application enforces your organization's audit policy with respect to managing its logs. Check that:
          
            Your application does not erase older log entries before they are deemed expired by your organization's audit policy. If your application performs log rotation, ensure that older logs are stored by a unique identifier to prevent unintentional deletion of older log entries. Your application logs user activity but not user-supplied data. For example, log the event that a user changed their password, but not the password itself. Your application does not append user-supplied data to an exception's message and/or details.
          
          
            
              Verify that ASP.NET health monitoring is secured. If your application uses ASP.NET health monitoring (a feature that is enabled by default), check if the following measures are set in place:
            
              
                Logs are throttled: Depending on your application's requirements, ensure that your application's logs are properly throttled. Consult the Consider Log Throttling guideline for more details. Connection strings are secured: Ensure that all connection strings that are used by your application's logging framework are properly secured. Use the Connection Strings are Secured checklist to aid you in this task.

Log files are located on a non-system NTFS volume and not on the same volume where the Web site content resides.

Verify that ASP.NET health monitoring is secured. If your application uses ASP.NET health monitoring (a feature that is enabled by default), check if the following measures are set in place:

Consult the Consider Log Throttling guideline for more details. Connection strings are secured: Ensure that all connection strings that are used by your application's logging framework are properly secured. Use the Connection Strings are Secured checklist to aid you in this task.

For more information about setting secure filesystem permission to log files, see: How to set secure NTFS permissions on IIS 5.0 log files and virtual directories in Windows 2000.
To learn more about log rotation in IIS, visit: HOW TO: View and Report from Log Files.
To learn more about securing ASP.NET health monitoring, visit Securing ASP.NET Health Monitoring on MSDN.

a: How to set secure NTFS permissions on IIS 5.0 log files and virtual directories in Windows 2000
HOW TO: View and Report from Log Files

links.text: How to set secure NTFS permissions on IIS 5.0 log files and virtual directories in Windows 2000
HOW TO: View and Report from Log Files

html:
What to Check For

Ensure access to your application's log files are restricted.

Why

Logged events often contain internal application details that could enable an attacker to more effectively target your application.

How to Check

If your application generates multiple log files, use your application to generate all the log files and follow these steps to ensure they are protected:

  1. Verify location of logs is not disclosed. Scan your application's code base to verify that the location of the log files is known only to the internal logging framework.

  2. Ensure appropriate Access Control Lists (ACL) are set. Verify that:

    • Logs are set with the appropriate file system permissions.
    • All entities, excluding your application and its administrators/developers, are prohibited access to the logs.
    • If your application logs are backed up, verify that the backups are stored in an environment that is secure.
    • Log files are located on a non-system NTFS volume and not on the same volume where the Web site content resides.

  3. Ensure that proper log management is in place. Verify that your application enforces your organization's audit policy with respect to managing its logs. Check that:

    • Your application does not erase older log entries before they are deemed expired by your organization's audit policy.
    • If your application performs log rotation, ensure that older logs are stored by a unique identifier to prevent unintentional deletion of older log entries.
    • Your application logs user activity but not user-supplied data. For example, log the event that a user changed their password, but not the password itself.
    • Your application does not append user-supplied data to an exception's message and/or details.

  4. Verify that ASP.NET health monitoring is secured. If your application uses ASP.NET health monitoring (a feature that is enabled by default), check if the following measures are set in place:

    • Logs are throttled: Depending on your application's requirements, ensure that your application's logs are properly throttled. Consult the Consider Log Throttling guideline for more details.
    • Connection strings are secured: Ensure that all connection strings that are used by your application's logging framework are properly secured. Use the Connection Strings are Secured checklist to aid you in this task.

Problem Example

An e-commerce site does hundreds of transactions an hour and logs data at the web and database levels, along with a separate security log that monitors all user and security-related events. Unfortunately, the security logs are stored in a location that is hidden in the application's directory tree. An attacker finds the location of the logs and retrieves all user and security-related events.

Additional Resources

  • For more information about setting secure filesystem permission to log files, see: How to set secure NTFS permissions on IIS 5.0 log files and virtual directories in Windows 2000.
  • To learn more about log rotation in IIS, visit: HOW TO: View and Report from Log Files.
  • To learn more about securing ASP.NET health monitoring, visit Securing ASP.NET Health Monitoring on MSDN.

Related Guideline

  • Guideline: Protect Log Files

Adapted from Microsoft patterns & practices guidance.
